metaphor.core: The time loop experienced by Major William Cage in 'Edge of Tomorrow', where he relives the same battle repeatedly, serves as a metaphor for React's re-rendering process. The module demonstrates how `React.memo` (and `useMemo`/`useCallback`) allows components to 'skip' unnecessary re-renders when their props haven't changed, conserving computational 'energy' and 'execution time' by recognizing already-solved 'battlefields' and focusing resources only on new 'threats' (changed props).

mapping.fictionElement: Major William Cage reliving the day/battle
mapping.reactConcept: A React component undergoing repeated re-renders.

mapping.fictionElement: The Relentless Render (start of each loop)
mapping.reactConcept: React's default behavior: when a parent component re-renders, all its children re-render by default, even if their props haven't changed.

mapping.fictionElement: Brute-Force Approach (Cage repeatedly fighting the same way)
mapping.reactConcept: Components that re-execute expensive computations or logic on every render, even when their props are identical to the previous render, leading to wasted resources.

mapping.fictionElement: Rita explaining to 'skip battles already won' / The Recognition Principle
mapping.reactConcept: `React.memo`: a Higher-Order Component that memoizes a functional component, preventing it from re-rendering if its props are shallowly equal to the previous props.
The props received by a component, which `React.memo` performs a shallow comparison against.
The performance benefits of `React.memo` in reducing unnecessary computations, CPU cycles, and improving application responsiveness.

mapping.fictionElement: The Symphony of Optimization (Cage strategically skipping sectors)
mapping.reactConcept: Applying `React.memo` strategically to optimize performance by preventing re-renders of components whose props (and internal state derived from props) have not changed.

metaphor.narrativeArc: The module follows Cage's journey through the time loop. It starts with the 'relentless render' (default React re-rendering), exposes the inefficiency of the 'brute-force approach' (unoptimized components), introduces the 'recognition principle' (`React.memo`) as a solution, compares 'effort vs. memory' (cost of re-rendering vs. benefits of memoization), and culminates in a 'symphony of optimization' where `React.memo` is applied strategically across a component tree.

problems: Components re-rendering unnecessarily, leading to wasted CPU cycles and slower UI updates
Complex or expensive computations re-executing on every render

chapters.title: The Relentless Render
chapters.focus: Introduces the default behavior of React re-renders: all children re-render when a parent does.

chapters.title: The Brute-Force Approach
chapters.focus: Demonstrates the performance cost of unnecessary re-renders in components performing expensive work.

chapters.title: The Recognition Principle
chapters.focus: Explains `React.memo` as a way to prevent unnecessary re-renders by performing a shallow comparison of props.

chapters.title: Effort vs. Memory
chapters.focus: Compares the performance impact (execution time, resource usage) of brute-force re-rendering versus memoized optimization.

chapters.title: The Symphony of Optimization
chapters.focus: Illustrates how to strategically apply `React.memo` to optimize an application's component tree for maximum efficiency.

interactiveElements: Simulating parent component re-renders and observing child component re-render counts (both memoized and non-memoized)
Visualizing 'energy' depletion due to brute-force re-renders
Interactive toggle between memoized and non-memoized component rendering
Comparing execution times and render counts between optimized and unoptimized scenarios
Interactive battlefield simulation where individual 'sectors' (components) can have their props changed to trigger selective re-renders in a memoized setup.
